About the Brand:
Oliver was a short-lived experimental line created under the Valentino umbrella in the 1990s. It represented the brand’s playful side, focusing on bold shapes and forward-looking materials. While Valentino remained rooted in classic Italian luxury, Oliver explored sport-luxe silhouettes and vibrant colorways, making these frames a rare example of Valentino’s venture into avant-garde eyewear design.

column3:
Inuit Goggles (19th–early 20th century, design dating back millennia)
Carved from bone, antler, or wood, Inuit snow goggles are among the earliest known forms of eyewear. Their narrow slits shielded against snow blindness, blending necessity with artistry. Shown here in conversation with rare frames uncovered in Paris, they trace a lineage of eyewear as both survival tool and cultural expression—an archive of vision across time and place.

Paris Finds
From hidden optician basements to tucked-away vintage dealers, Paris reveals frames that embody decades of design history. Each pair carries the spirit of the city—refined, eclectic, and storied. Together with the Inuit goggles, these discoveries form a dialogue between cultures and eras, showing how eyewear has always been more than function: it is artistry, identity, and time itself made wearable.

Born from the same design house as the legendary Bugatti cars, these frames are a symbol of luxury precision. The 1980s saw Bugatti channel its engineering ethos into optical design—focusing on clean lines, lightweight materials, and a forward-thinking aesthetic. The double bridge and slim profile echo the brand’s dedication to both speed and subtlety.

Fit Description: Best suited for small faces. Ultra-lightweight and ergonomic—built to wear like a second skin.

column3:
A sculptural standout from the 1980s, The Archivist by Terri Brognan features oversized square lenses, rich brown tortoiseshell acetate, and a silhouette that commands attention without overpowering. The curved bridge and slight winged edges offer just enough flair—refined, bold, and completely one of a kind.

Designer: Terri Brognan
Country of Origin: Unknown
Decade: 1980s
Frame: Oversized square in warm tortoiseshell acetate
Lenses: No lenses installed – ready for prescription or sun lenses
Design Details: Saddle bridge, sculpted temples, subtle edge detailing
Condition: Excellent vintage deadstock – never worn
Additional Info: One-of-one, tags still intact

The Journey:
Sourced from a dusty eyewear warehouse in London, this frame was part of a massive deadstock archive from a family-run optical business. I met the founder’s son at an eyewear expo in Milan, where our conversation opened the door to a forgotten inventory of rare 20th-century frames. After traveling back to New York—tags untouched—this piece now waits to be seen again.

A sleek rarity from 1990s Matsuda, this titanium frame balances precision and poetry. With its slim oval lenses, barely-there bridge, and clean construction, the 101 14120 feels like a whisper of design—lightweight, but impossible to ignore. Made in Japan during the golden era of the brand’s craftsmanship, it’s a quiet statement for those who value nuance and legacy.

Pairs well with: people who read the footnotes, wear Comme des Garçons, or collect architecture books "for the pictures."

column3:
Step into the bold elegance of the 1980s with these Jean-Paul Gaultier 58-6201 sunglasses. Crafted in Japan, these iconic frames embody Gaultier’s daring and unconventional design philosophy, blending high fashion with striking functionality.

Details:

  • Designer: Jean-Paul Gaultier
  • Model: 58-6201
  • Decade: 1980s
  • Design: Made in Japan, showcasing superior craftsmanship and precision combining bronze double temples with peach acetate side shields and windsor rings. JPG logo printed on side shields. 
  • Frame Description: Sleek, sculptural design with intricate detailing, capturing Gaultier's avant-garde aesthetic.
  • Lenses Description: Original lenses with a bold tint, perfectly preserved in their unworn state.
  • Design: Made in Japan, showcasing superior craftsmanship and precision.
  • Condition: New, unworn deadstock from the 1980s, offering a rare collector's item

Care Instructions:
Each pair comes with a cleaning cloth to keep your lenses pristine and ready for wear.

Jean-Paul Gaultier was at the avant-garde of eyewear design in the 1980s. Although Japan was by far the most expensive place of production for eyewear frames at that time, Gaultier did not want to settle with anything less than the best craftsmanship for his sunglasses and had his designs produced by the best of the best: MURAI Japan. Unlike most other designers, he did not just license his brand to a big eyewear manufacturer but instead kept a minute supervision of the design and production of his sunglasses until 1999, when he left MURAI and started to produce in Italy.

Note: While it may not be directly related, these sunglasses share the same name as Tōshūsai Sharaku, a renowned Japanese artist known for his striking ukiyo-e portraits. Sharaku's career was remarkably short-lived, lasting only about 10 months between 1794 and 1795, but his work left a lasting impact on Japanese art.

A must-have for vintage eyewear collectors and fashion enthusiasts alike, these frames offer sustainable luxury and a touch of understated sophistication.

“Crystalize” 1960s Mozetta Sunglasses

Introducing “Crystalize,” a stunning pair of 1960s vintage sunglasses by Mozetta, designed in France. These beautiful powder blue frames, with a subtle cat eye shape, exude timeless elegance and sophistication. Embellished with Swarovski crystals on each side, these artisan-crafted sunglasses offer a perfect blend of luxury and glamour.

Featuring newly added grey polarized lenses, these sunglasses provide both style and functionality. A unique and rare piece of sustainable fashion, “Crystalize” is the epitome of bespoke vintage eyewear.

Details:

  • Designer: Mozetta
  • Era: 1960s
  • Country of Origin: France
  • Lenses: New grey polarized lenses
  • Condition: Very good (slight signs of wear, including rubbing off text on ear pieces)

Introducing "Retro Vision," a pair of luxurious 1980s Cazal vintage glasses that exude high-fashion, exclusivity, and timeless elegance. With a stunning gold frame and striking royal blue and teal details at each earpiece, these eyeglasses are a true symbol of craftsmanship. The fresh blue lenses are a bespoke touch, designed to perfectly complement the glasses' unique color accents.

Handcrafted in West Germany, this eyewear set reflects the era's distinctive style and cutting-edge design. Whether you're a collector or fashion enthusiast, these vintage Cazals offer both sustainable fashion and unparalleled quality.

Details:

The royal blue and teal accents provide a bold statement, while the new blue lenses are custom-fitted to reflect the true spirit of the 1980s.

Introducing the LA Eyeworks "HARP" eyewear, an exclusive piece of 1990s design made in Italy. 100% of proceeds will be donated to Ukraine. Item will be auctioned in Silent Mixed Media Auction that will take place on Sun, 7/9 in Connecticut at the Ukrainian American Club.

 

 

“Irish-Ukrainian Founder, Maureen Ryza, presents “Resilient Reflections.” 

1980 Persol Ratti frames rehabilitated with UV-protected blue and yellow lenses. Made in Italy, remodeled in NYC.

The bonded crack on this vintage frame holds more significance than meets the eye. It's a symbol of the country's unwavering strength and determination in the face of adversity. Despite the challenges and struggles that Ukraine has faced, it has managed to rise above and emerge victorious. This crack reminds us that Ukraine will not be broken, and its people will continue to persevere no matter what comes their way.

Put them on and feel the indomitable spirit of the Ukrainian people.”

 

Starting bid $1,000

Step into the elegance of 1960s French eyewear design with these exquisite oval rimless frames. Featuring a unique floating bridge crafted from striped acetate, mimicking the look of wood grain, these glasses are a true testament to mid-century minimalism blended with artistic boldness.

Details:

  • Era: 1960s
  • Made in: France
  • Design: Oval rimless lenses with a distinctive floating bridge
  • Features: Comfortable plastic nose pieces for durability

Lens Customization:

These frames are ready for customization, as they currently have no lenses. Whether you need prescription or tinted lenses, these glasses can be tailored to meet your needs, offering a bespoke eyewear experience.

Perfect for collectors, fashion enthusiasts, or anyone who values distinctive design, these frames capture the essence of timeless elegance and individuality. Redefine your style with this extraordinary piece of 1960s eyewear craftsmanship.

COLANI! One of our favorite design brains to ever exist. These frames were made in Japan and boast an extremely unique design. Why blend in when you can stand out?

Luigi Colani is said to have created over 4,000 designs in his lifetime. Cars, cameras, pianos, furniture; you name it. Each has specific characteristics that make it immediately identifiable as a Colani piece. A man ahead of his time.

column3:
1950s layered acetate frames, made in France.

Without Altina Schinasi Miranda, American Filmmaker and Designer, eyewear would not be what it is today. Walking down 5th Ave in the 1920s, Miranda found herself uninspired by the unisex frame options. A Dorothy Parker line came to mind — “Men seldom make passes at girls that wear glasses” — and Schinasi set out to make a pair of glasses that would make a woman look and feel attractive. She took inspiration from Venetian Harlequin masks and thus the Harlequin (later known as the cat-eye) glasses were born. By the end of the 1930s, harlequin glasses had become so popular that Schinasi started her own company to distribute them. In 1939, she was given the American Design Award from Lord and Taylor for revolutionising the eyewear industry and transforming optical glasses into a fashion accessory. Vogue Scandinavia

column3: MADE IN GERMANY IN THE 1980S BY EYEWEAR DESIGNER, "CAZAL." THESE FRAMES HAVE A PEARL-ESQUE FEEL TO THEM IN THEIR RECTANGULAR SHAPE PAIRED WITH LIGHT BLUE LENSES.<br data-mce-fragment="1"><br data-mce-fragment="1">THEIR FOCUS ON QUALITY IS KEY, WITH EVERY PAIR GOING THROUGH 35 DIFFERENT PROCESSES AND EVERY HINGE UNDERGOING 50,000 DIFFERENT MOTIONS TO ENSURE QUALITY AND DURABILITY SINCE THE VERY BEGINNING.<br data-mce-fragment="1"><br data-mce-fragment="1">CAZAL WAS FIRST CREATED IN 1979 BY AUSTRIAN CARI ZALLONI, WHO SAW HIS FRAMES DISTRIBUTED FIRST IN GERMANY. DESPITE HIS EARLY DESIGNS BEING VERY STYLISH AND BOASTING HIGH QUALITY MATERIALS, THEY REMAINED A LONG WAY FROM THE GLOBAL MAINSTREAM.<br data-mce-fragment="1"><br data-mce-fragment="1">THINGS STARTED TO CHANGE IN THE EARLY 80’S HOWEVER, AS THE ICONIC 607S WERE PICKED UP BY MORE AND MORE DISTRIBUTORS ACROSS EUROPE AND FURTHER AFIELD. ONCE DARRYL MCDANIELS OF RUN D.M.C WAS SEEN ROCKING A PAIR OF 607S, THE US MARKET BEGAN TO CLAMOUR FOR THEM, AND POPULARITY SOARED ALL OVER AMERICA.<br data-mce-fragment="1"><br data-mce-fragment="1">CAZAL SPECS BECAME AN INSTANT HIT IN AMERICA, WHERE EYEWEAR WAS STARTING TO BE USED FOR FASHION RATHER THAN FOR A PURELY FUNCTIONAL BASIS FOR THE FIRST TIME EVER. [1980S]
column7: vintage, vintage designer, vintage dior, vintage frames, vintage glasses, vintage sun, VINTAGE SUNGLASS, vintage sunglasses

column3:
Remodeled PAIR OF JEAN-FRANÇOIS REY GLASSES FROM THE BEGINNING OF THE BRAND IN THE 1990S. MADE IN FRANCE. THESE FRAMES ARE AN EXPLOSION OF RED, ORANGE, AND YELLOW, WITH TWO DEEP NOSE PIECES. WE REPLACED THE LENSES WITH BRAND NEW SCRATCH-RESISTANT, UV-PROTECTED ORANGE LENSES. THESE GLASSES EVOKE HAPPINESS AS SOON AS TOUCHING YOUR FACE. THE WORLD GETS BRIGHTER. :-) right leg is a bit loose and fragile, but nothing major. The glasses are 30 years old afterall. 

PLAYING BETWEEN TRADITION AND INNOVATION, JEAN-FRANÇOIS REY IS MARKED BY ELEGANCE AND ORIGINALITY. ACCORDING TO THEIR WEBSITE, “OUR FRAMES ARE MADE WITH THE GREATEST RESPECT FOR MATERIALS AND THE MASTERY OF VERSATILE KNOW-HOW.”

column3:
COLANI 76-5002 BY MURAI, MADE IN JAPAN IN 1990S. 

THESE BLACK FRAMES WITH A RUBBER COATING FOLD UP TO RETRACT AROUND WIRELESS GREEN LENSES.


“THE NATURAL WORLD IS MADE UP OF CURVED LINES.” LUIGI COLANI WAS THE MASTER OF ORGANIC DESIGN, HE WAS INSPIRED BY SHAPES AND FORMS HE'D FIND IN NATURE: "THE FUSION OF FUNCTION, RATIONALITY AND HUMAN NATURE" WHICH COLANI CALLED "BIO-TECHNIC DESIGN.”

THIS VERY RARE AND ABSOLUTELY UNIQUE PIECE COMES FROM THE SECOND ERA OF JAPANESE MADE COLANI EYEWEAR: AFTER A LONG COLLABORATION WITH THE MANUFACTURER OPTOS, COLANI MADE A VERY SHORT PRODUCTION RUN WITH THE ICONIC MURAI MANUFACTURE WHO DESIGNED AND PRODUCED ALL OF JEAN PAUL GAULTIER'S MASTERPIECES FROM THE 1980-1990 ERA.
